awd_titl_txt: AitF: Provenance with Privacy and Reliability in Federated Distributed Systems
awd_abstract_narration: The goal of this project is to investigate the question of provenance in federated distributed systems, such as networks and scientific workflows, where several self-interested entities generate and share data, and compute and make decisions on the shared data.  Computations and decisions give rise themselves to new shared data.  Provenance analysis allows us to understand the contributions of the various entities to the data.  This project seeks to put provenance on a sound mathematical foundation by unifying the theoretical notion of semiring provenance with practical approaches to network provenance.  The PIs would also like to design new algorithms and compression techniques for collecting and managing provenance data.  A second thrust of the project is to compute and associate reliability scores to each data item, in conjunction with their provenance.  In order to do this, the PIs will design techniques for assigning reliability scores to primitive data items, as well as a calculus based on sound axiomatic principles for assigning reliability scores to derived data items.  This project will achieve broad impact by allowing for networks to operate more reliably and by enhancing reproducibility in scientific workflows.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: TRUSTEES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA, THE

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Trustees of the University of Pennsylvania

por.por_cntn:
The project sought to make advances in the definitions and implementations of the notions of privacy and of  provenance tracking where the goal is to track the origin of pieces of information, be they raw data or data obtained by combination and processing of other data. Above all the project was concerned with how to navigate the tension between privacy and provenance-tracking, and whether it was possible to have both.

The project made significant advances on ways of achieving privacy in various contexts, for example in matching residents to hospitals or students to universities, as well as in kidney-exchange-type markets. The project also produced efficient ways of providing privacy between users using a shared resource on the network. 

On provenance, the project made fundamental contributions in putting an algebraic structure on this notion, thereby providing the ability to mathematically reason about it. It also gave ways of maintaining provenance under incremental changes to the data.

In the area of combining provenance and privacy, the project made some seminal contributions on tracking the source of faults in a network, while protecting the privacy of honest users. Several systems for doing this and similar tasks were developed under this project. These include Mycelium, Orchard, and Honeycrisp all developed by PI Haeberlen and collaborators.


Last Modified: 01/14/2023
Modified by: Sampath Kannan
